column1: Mittweida (German pronunciation: [mɪtˈvaɪda]) is a town in the Free State of Saxony
Mittweida is situated on the Zschopau River
column3: and 54 km west of Dresden. Embedded within the steep hills and valleys of the river and two smaller creeks
column4: the town is green and picturesque.

column1: Mittweida has a station on the Riesa–Chemnitz railway. A branch line
column3: served the industries in nearby Dreiwerden and Ringethal. Major roads are the state roads S200
column6: connecting the town with various federal roads and the motorway A4 which passes south-east of Mittweida.

column1: The town was first mentioned in 1209. In 1286 it was known as civitas and oppidum. Weaving of wool and linen were major occupations of the inhabitants in the Middle Ages
column2: and after a spinning mill was founded in 1816
column3: the town grew into one of the major textile-producing centers in Saxony of the 20th century. Mittweida was already a sizeable town in the mid-16th century
column4: and despite having more inhabitants than Rochlitz
column5: it had remained part of Amt and Amtshauptmannschaft Rochlitz for many years. In 1924 it became a separate urban district. During World War II
column6: a subcamp of Flossenbürg concentration camp was located in Mittweida. In 1946 the town was reintegrated into Landkreis Rochlitz and was transferred to Kreis Hainichen in 1952. Landkreis Mittweida was formed from the districts Rochlitz and Hainichen in 1994
column7: it was integrated into Landkreis Mittelsachsen in 2008.

column1: Of interest are the Gothic church from the 15/16th century
column3: the historic and technical museums and the nearby Kriebstein castle.

column1: Mittweida is home to a University of Applied Sciences with about 5000 students. Founded in the late 19th century
column2: it is known far beyond the Saxon borders. Among its students were August Horch
Head of Amt VII of the Reichsicherheitshauptamt and SS Obersturmburführer
